title: David Winnie
text:
David Peter Winnie (born 26 October 1966) is a Scottish former <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> of <a href="Dumbarton%20F.C.">Dumbarton</a>. He is presently a solicitor. 
A <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> on the field, Winnie was part of <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren's</a> <a href="1987%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">1987 Scottish Cup Final</a>-winning team. He also played for <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a>, <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a> and <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a>, and was a <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Scotland U21</a> international. After leaving Scotland in 1998, he played for KR Reykjavik where he won the Icelandic player of the year. In 1999, Winnie helped KR win the Icelandic Premier League and Cup for the first time in 30 years, following which he went on loan to Canberra Cosmos in Australia for a season before returning to Iceland.
In 2001, Winnie was then assistant manager at <a href="KR%20Reykjavik">KR</a> before a brief caretaker role saw him steer them from relegation danger. Winnie was then part of the youth academy coaching staff at <a href="Livingston%20F.C.">Livingston</a> and <a href="Glasgow%20Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a>.
Winnie was manager of <a href="Dumbarton%20F.C.">Dumbarton</a> from June 2002 until his sacking in March 2003, when the "Sons" were struggling in the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a>. He was replaced by <a href="Bo%27ness%20United">Bo'ness United</a> manager <a href="Brian%20Fairley">Brian Fairley</a>.
Winnie trained to become a solicitor at a law firm in <a href="St.%20Albans">St. Albans</a> and qualified in November 2009. He became head of the Sports Law Department at Blaser Mills Law, a law firm with offices in the City of London and south east England.
Honours.
St Mirren
KR Reykjavík
